item.title: ggsci 4.0.0: 400+ new color palettes
item.description: Cozy autumn vibes: a warm drink, a good book, and colorful leaves. Photo by Alisa Anton. After the last update in June 2024, I am excited to announce the release of ggsci 4.0.0 and ggsci for Python 1.0.0. You can install the R package ggsci from CRAN: install.packages("ggsci") And install the Python package from PyPI: pip install ggsci This update brings over 400 new discrete color palettes for ggplot2 and plotnine visualizations.

item.title: Introducing py-ggsci: ggsci color palettes for plotnine in Python
item.description: Cliff Walk at Pourville (1882) by Claude Monet: two women on a grassy cliff above the sea under a bright sky. Public domain. Source: Art Institute of Chicago. I’m thrilled to announce the release of py-ggsci, a Python package that brings the popular ggsci color palettes from R’s ggplot2 ecosystem to Python’s plotnine library. You can install py-ggsci from PyPI: pip install ggsci Here is a quick example using the Observable 10 palette introduced in ggsci 3.

item.title: ggsci 3.1.0, ggsurvfit example, and reverse dependency check
item.description: Photo by Elena Mozhvilo. I am excited to announce the release of ggsci 3.1.0. ggsci is an R package that provides a collection of color palettes inspired by colors used in scientific journals, data visualization libraries, science fiction movies, and TV shows. To install ggsci from CRAN, run: install.packages("ggsci") This release introduces a new color scale and brings documentation improvements. This post demonstrates how to create a Kaplan-Meier plot using ggsurvfit, cowplot, and ggsci.

item.description: Cute market in Rome, Italy. Photo by Mark Pecar. Maintaining R packages is a significant time and effort commitment. item.title: Rethinking the Word Cloud Generator

item.title: ggsci 3.0.0
item.description: 3D render from Rodion Kutsaiev. I am delighted to announce the release of ggsci 3.0.0. ggsci provides a collection of color palettes inspired by colors used in scientific journals, data visualization libraries, science fiction movies, and TV shows. You can install it from CRAN with: install.packages("ggsci") This version brings 7 new color palettes under 3 color scales (COSMIC, Flat UI, Frontiers), multiple improvements, and a new FAQ vignette, giving you more options to create effective data visualizations using ggplot2.

item.title: Adaptive ggplot2 Color Scales with Color Interpolation
item.description: Photo by Mateo Giraud. My R package ggsci has included a few popular discrete color palettes. The colors values in these palettes are not automatically generated from a color space but hand-picked instead, often containing only five to ten distinct colors. A frequent question from the users is: What should I do when the colors are running out due to a more significant number of categories in the data?
